factoid: Pierre imagined himself calmed by such reflections.
Pierre had most strongly expressed his insincere love for Hélène.
Pierre felt the blood rush to his heart.
Pierre had to get up and move about and break and tear whatever came to his hand.
Pierre repeated to himself, "Why did I tell her that Je vous aime?".
Molière's words "Mais que diable allait-il faire dans cette galère?" occurred to Pierre.
Pierre laughed at himself.
Pierre called his valet and told him to pack up to go to Petersburg.
Pierre could not imagine how he could speak to Hélène now.
Pierre resolved to go away the next day and leave a letter informing Hélène of his intention to part from her forever.
The next morning, the valet came into the room with his coffee.
Pierre was lying asleep on the ottoman with an open book in his hand.
Pierre woke up and looked round with a startled expression.
The valet told Pierre that the countess had told him to inquire whether Pierre's excellency was at home.
The countess entered the room in a white satin dressing gown embroidered with silver.
The countess had her hair in two immense plaits twice round her lovely head like a coronet.
The countess was calm and majestic.
The countess had a wrathful wrinkle on her rather prominent marble brow.
The countess did not begin to speak in front of the valet.
The countess knew of the duel.
The countess had come to speak about the duel.
The countess waited until the valet had set down the coffee.
Pierre looked at the countess timidly over his spectacles.
Pierre tried to continue reading.
Pierre again glanced timidly at the countess.
The countess looked at Pierre with a contemptuous smile, waiting for the valet to go.
The countess asked Pierre sternly, "Well, what’s this now? What have you been up to now, I should like to know?".
Pierre stammered, "I? What have I?".
The countess said, "So it seems you’re a hero, eh? Come now, what was this duel about? What is it meant to prove? What? I ask you.".
Pierre turned over heavily on the ottoman and opened his mouth, but could not reply.
The countess said, "If you won’t answer, I’ll tell you...".
The countess said, "You believe everything you’re told.".
The countess said, "You were told...".
The countess laughed, "that Dólokhov was my lover.".
The countess said, "You believed it!".
The countess said, "What have you proved? What does this duel prove?".
The countess said, "That you’re a fool, que vous êtes un sot, but everybody knew that.".

The countess said, "What will be the result? That I shall be the laughingstock of all Moscow, that everyone will say that you, drunk and not knowing what you were about, challenged a man you are jealous of without cause.".
The countess raised her voice and became more and more excited.
The countess said, "A man who’s a better man than you in every way...".
Pierre growled, "Hm... Hm...!" and frowning without looking at the countess.
The countess said, "And how could you believe he was my lover? Why? Because I like his company? If you were cleverer and more agreeable, I should prefer yours.".
Pierre muttered, "Don’t speak to me... I beg you.".

The countess answered, "Why shouldn’t I speak? I can speak as I like, and I tell you plainly that there are not many wives with husbands such as you who would not have taken lovers, but I have not done so.".
Pierre looked at the countess with eyes whose strange expression she did not understand, and lay down again.
Pierre was suffering physically at that moment, there was a weight on his chest and he could not breathe.
Pierre knew that he must do something to put an end to this suffering.
Pierre wanted to do something, but what he wanted to do was too terrible.
Pierre muttered, "We had better separate.".
